Once you figure out the important variables or ideas, you need to ask a specific question about the next step you want to take with those variables. For example, if you're writing a book chapter, your question might be, “How do I start this chapter well?” If you're working on a proof, it could be, “What could go wrong if I don’t assume this rule is true?” Once you have your variables and your next-step question, you know exactly what to focus on.

If you can answer your next-step question, the last part of this thinking process is to review your answer clearly. After that, you can challenge yourself to go deeper by starting the process again. This cycle of reviewing what you learned, figuring out the next question, and then solidifying your understanding is like a workout for your brain. It helps you get more out of your focused thinking sessions and speeds up how quickly you can improve your ability to concentrate.

Daniel Kilov can memorize a shuffled deck of cards, a hundred random digits, or 115 random shapes in just five minutes. He even set a national record in Australia for memorizing shapes! It’s no surprise that he won silver medals in the Australian memory championships. What’s surprising is that Kilov didn’t always have an amazing memory.

He said, “I wasn’t born with a great memory.” In high school, he thought he was forgetful and messy. He had a tough time in school and was diagnosed with attention deficit disorder. Everything changed when he met Tansel Ali, a famous memory champion, and decided to train his memory seriously. By the time he graduated college, he had already won his first medal in a national competition.

Kilov’s quick rise to becoming a top memory athlete is impressive, but it’s not the only story like this. In 2006, Joshua Foer, an American writer, won the USA Memory Championship after just a year of hard training, which he wrote about in his book, *Moonwalking with Einstein*. What’s really interesting about Kilov’s journey is how his memory training improved his school performance. While working on his memory, he went from struggling in school to graduating from a tough Australian university.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Daniel Kilov transformed from a forgetful student to a memory champion through dedicated training. He learned to focus on specific questions and review his answers, improving both his memory and academic performance significantly. His story shows that with effort, anyone can enhance their skills.
